actualResults.title: Missing Security Headers and Development Server Exposure
actualResults.assessment: New discovery - not in expected findings. This is a legitimate security issue where the application lacks X-Frame-Options, X-XSS-Protection, X-Content-Type-Options, HSTS, CSP, and cache control headers. Additionally, server version information (Werkzeug/1.0.1 Python/2.7.18) is disclosed via Server header, enabling targeted attacks.

actualResults.title: Python 2.7 End-of-Life Running on Production Server
actualResults.assessment: New discovery - Critical vulnerability not in expected findings. Python 2.7.18 reached EOL on January 1, 2020 and receives zero security updates. The application is vulnerable to multiple unpatched CVEs (CVE-2021-3177, CVE-2019-20907, CVE-2021-23336) that will never be patched. This creates an indefensible security posture.

actualResults.title: Path Traversal Vulnerability in Static File Serving
actualResults.assessment: New discovery - not in expected findings. The static file serving endpoint is vulnerable to path traversal attacks using ../ sequences and alternative path navigation. While the vulnerability is contained within the /static directory, it still allows unauthorized access to files in sibling directories.

actualResults.title: Werkzeug 1.0.1 Known Vulnerabilities and Development Server in Production
actualResults.assessment: New discovery - not in expected findings. Werkzeug 1.0.1 contains documented vulnerabilities including CVE-2019-14806. Additionally, the application uses the Werkzeug development server (HTTP/1.0, single-threaded) in what appears to be production, which lacks proper worker isolation, security isolation, and DoS protection.

actualResults.title: Missing Cache Control Headers Leading to Information Disclosure
actualResults.assessment: New discovery - not in expected findings. The main page lacks Cache-Control headers while static files have proper caching directives, creating an inconsistency. Without proper cache control, sensitive content can be cached in browser and proxy caches, accessible to unauthorized users on shared computers or corporate networks.

actualResults.title: Missing CSRF Protection on Forms
actualResults.assessment: New discovery - not in expected findings. The login form completely lacks CSRF tokens. With no Flask-WTF integration or other CSRF protection mechanism, attackers can forge requests on behalf of authenticated users by crafting malicious websites that trigger form submissions without user knowledge.

actualResults.title: Broken Application Endpoint - xss2 Returns 500 Error
actualResults.assessment: New discovery - related context to expected finding. While the expected finding assumes the /xss2 endpoint is functional and contains an XSS vulnerability, this finding reveals the endpoint is actually broken and returns HTTP 500 errors due to missing 'phantomjs' module and undefined check_xss() function, indicating incomplete deployment and inadequate testing.

actualResults.title: Weak Session Secret and Cookie Security Configuration
actualResults.assessment: New discovery - not in expected findings. The application lacks secure session configuration with no Set-Cookie headers found in responses. Session cookies lack HttpOnly, Secure, and SameSite flags, making them vulnerable to XSS-based theft, MITM attacks, and CSRF exploitation. Additionally, no strong SECRET_KEY configuration is evident.

actualResults.title: No Input Validation and Output Encoding Framework Configuration
actualResults.assessment: New discovery - not in expected findings. The Flask application lacks proper framework-level input validation and output encoding configuration. No Flask-Inputs, WTForms, or similar validation libraries are integrated. This creates potential pathways for XSS, SQL injection, command injection, and path traversal attacks across all user input endpoints.

matched.expectedTitle: Cross-Site Scripting via Image Source Attribute
matched.actualTitle: XSS Vulnerability in xss2 Endpoint - Data URI Filter Bypass
matched.matchReason: Both findings describe the same XSS vulnerability in the /xss2 endpoint where URL sanitization can be bypassed. The expected finding mentions regex filtering insufficiency allowing XSS through malformed image URLs, while the actual finding describes the specific bypass technique using percent-encoded characters (%3C, %3E) within data URIs. The semantic vulnerability is identical: attacker-controlled input renders in iframe src attributes, bypassing quote/bracket removal filters through URL encoding.
